1.verse: Daniel Taken to Babylon - During the third year that Jehoiakim was king of Judah [605 BC], Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon [ruled 605–562 BC] came to Jerusalem and ·surrounded it with his army [besieged/pressed it].

2.verse: The Lord ·allowed Nebuchadnezzar to capture Jehoiakim king of Judah [gave Jehoiakim king of Judah into his hand; God was in control, not Nebuchadnezzar]. Nebuchadnezzar also took some of the ·things [articles; utensils; cups, forks, and other items used in ritual; 5:2–4; Ex. 27:9; 30:27; 31:8–9; Ezra 1:9–11] from the ·Temple [house] of God, which he carried to ·Babylonia [the land of Shinar] and put in the ·temple [house of the treasury] of his ·gods [or god; probably Marduk, the chief god of Babylon].

3.verse: Then King Nebuchadnezzar ordered Ashpenaz, ·his chief officer [or the chief of his eunuchs], to bring some of the ·men of Judah into his palace. He wanted them to be from important families, including the family of the king of Judah […sons of Israel, from the royal family and from the nobility].

4.verse: King Nebuchadnezzar wanted only ·young Israelite men [children] who had ·nothing wrong with them [no blemish; 2 Sam. 14:25; Song 4:4]. They were to be ·handsome [of good appearance] and ·well educated [skilled in all wisdom], ·capable of learning [knowing knowledge] and understanding, and able to ·serve [stand] in his palace [Gen. 41:33]. Ashpenaz was to teach them the language and ·writings [literature] of the ·Babylonians [Chaldeans; probably Akkadian and Aramaic; the literature would include myths and legends as well as divination texts].

5.verse: The king ·gave the young men [allotted/assigned to them] ·a certain amount of food and wine every day, just like the food he ate [a daily ration of the royal food and wine he drank]. The young men were to be ·trained [educated] for three years, and then they would ·become servants of the king of Babylon [stand before the king].

6.verse: Among those young men were Daniel [“God is my judge”], Hananiah [“The LORD is gracious to me”], Mishael [“Who is like God”], and Azariah [“The LORD is my helper”] from the ·people [sons] of Judah.

7.verse: Ashpenaz, the chief ·officer [or of the eunuchs], gave them names [Babylonian, that is Akkadian, names]. Daniel’s new name was Belteshazzar, Hananiah’s was Shadrach, Mishael’s was Meshach, and Azariah’s was Abednego [the new names praised Babylonian gods].

8.verse: Daniel ·decided [set his heart] not to eat the king’s food or drink his wine because that would ·defile [contaminate] him [perhaps would make him ritually unclean, but more likely because he depended on God to sustain him]. So he ·asked [sought] ·Ashpenaz [the chief officer/or of the eunuchs] for permission not to ·defile [contaminate] himself in this way.

9.verse: God made Ashpenaz, the chief ·officer [or of the eunuchs], want to be ·kind [loving] and ·merciful [gracious] to Daniel,

10.verse: but ·Ashpenaz [the chief officer/or of the eunuchs] said to Daniel, “I am afraid of my master, the king. He ·ordered me to give you this [allotted/assigned your] food and drink. If you begin to look ·worse [thinner] than other ·young men [children; youth] your age, the king will see this. Then ·he will cut off my head because of you [you will forfeit my head to the king].”

11.verse: Daniel spoke to the ·guard [or attendant; steward] whom the chief ·officer [or of the eunuchs] had ·appointed [allotted/assigned] over Daniel, Hananiah, Mishael, and Azariah,

12.verse: “Please give us this test for ten days: Don’t give us anything but vegetables to eat and water to drink.

13.verse: Then compare how we look with how the other ·young men [children; youth] look who eat the king’s ·food [rations]. See for yourself and then decide how you want to treat us, your servants.”

14.verse: So the ·guard [or attendant; steward] ·agreed to test [listened to them on this matter and tested] them for ten days.

15.verse: After ten days they looked healthier and ·better fed [their flesh was fatter] than all the ·young men [children; youths] who ate the king’s ·food [rations].

16.verse: So the ·guard [or attendant; steward] took away the king’s special food and wine, feeding them vegetables instead.

17.verse: God gave these four ·young men [children; youths] ·wisdom [knowledge] and ·the ability to learn many things that people had written and studied [insight into wisdom and literature]. Daniel could also understand visions and dreams.

18.verse: At the end of the ·time [days] ·set for them by the king [which the king said to bring them; v. 5], ·Ashpenaz [the chief officer/or of the eunuchs] brought all the young men to King Nebuchadnezzar.

19.verse: The king talked to them and found that none of the young men were ·as good as [like] Daniel, Hananiah, Mishael, and Azariah. So ·those four young men became the king’s servants [they stood before the king].

20.verse: Every time the king ·asked them about [sought from them] something important, they showed much wisdom and understanding. They were ten times better than all the ·magicians [enchanters] and ·fortune-tellers [diviners] in his kingdom!

21.verse: So Daniel ·continued to be the king’s servant [was there] until the first year Cyrus was king.

1.verse: Nebuchadnezzar’s Dream - During Nebuchadnezzar’s second year as king [603–602 BC], ·he had dreams that bothered [his spirit agitated] him and ·kept him awake at night [his sleep left him].

2.verse: So the king ·called for [summoned] his ·magicians [enchanters], ·fortune-tellers [diviners], ·wizards [sorcerers], and ·wise men [Chaldeans; a group of astrologers], because he wanted them to tell him what he had dreamed. They came in and stood in front of the king.

3.verse: Then the king said to them, “I had a dream ·that bothers me [and my spirit is agitated], and I want to know ·what it means [the dream].”

4.verse: The ·wise men [astrologers; Chaldeans] answered the king in the Aramaic language [the language of the text shifts to Aramaic until the end of chapter 7; Aramaic was the everyday language of Babylon at this time], “O king, live forever! Please tell us, your servants, your dream. Then we will ·tell you what it means [interpret it].”

5.verse: King Nebuchadnezzar said to ·them [the astrologers/Chaldeans], “·I meant what I said [The matter has been determined by me]. You must tell me the dream and what it means. If you don’t, I will have you torn ·apart [limb from limb], and I will turn your houses into piles of stones [Ezra 6:11].

6.verse: But if you tell me my dream and its ·meaning [interpretation], I will reward you with gifts, a reward, and great honor. So tell me the dream and ·what it means [its interpretation].”

7.verse: Again the wise men said to the king, “Tell us, your servants, the dream, and we will tell you ·what it means [its interpretation].”

8.verse: ·King Nebuchadnezzar [The king] answered, “I know you are ·trying to get more [stalling for] time, because you know that ·I meant what I said [the matter has been determined by me].

9.verse: If you don’t tell me my dream, ·you will be punished [there is one ordinance/verdict for you]. You have all agreed to tell me lies and wicked things, hoping things will change. Now, tell me the dream so that I will know you can tell me ·what it really means [its interpretation]!”

10.verse: The ·wise men [astrologers; Chaldeans] answered the king, saying, “No one on earth can ·do [reveal] what the king asks! No great and powerful king has ever asked the ·magicians [enchanters], ·fortune tellers [diviners], or ·wise men [astrologers; Chaldeans] to do this [normally the dreamer would tell the dream, and the interpreter would interpret it using a dream commentary];

11.verse: the king is asking something that is too hard. Only the gods could tell the king this, but ·the gods do not live among people [their home/dwelling is not with flesh].”

12.verse: When the king heard their answer, he became very angry. He ordered that all the wise men of Babylon be killed.

13.verse: So King Nebuchadnezzar’s ·order [decree; edict] to kill the wise men was announced, and men ·were sent to look [searched] for Daniel and his friends to kill them [since they were also wise men].

14.verse: Arioch, the ·commander of the king’s guards [chief butcher], was going to kill the wise men of Babylon. But Daniel spoke to him with ·wisdom [prudence] and ·skill [deference],

15.verse: saying to Arioch, the royal official, “Why did the king order such a ·terrible [severe] punishment?” Then Arioch explained everything to Daniel.

16.verse: So Daniel went to King Nebuchadnezzar and asked for ·an appointment [or some time] so that he could tell the king what his dream meant.

17.verse: Then Daniel went to his house and ·explained the whole story [made the matter known] to his friends Hananiah, Mishael, and Azariah.

18.verse: Daniel asked his friends to ·pray [ask] that the God of heaven would show them ·mercy [compassion] and help them understand this ·secret [mystery] so he and his friends would not ·be killed [perish] with the other wise men of Babylon.

19.verse: During the night God ·explained [revealed] the ·secret [mystery] to Daniel in a vision. Then Daniel ·praised [blessed] the God of heaven.

20.verse: Daniel said: “·Praise [Blessed be] ·God [the name of God] forever and ever, because he has wisdom and ·power [might].

21.verse: He changes the times and seasons of the year. He ·takes away the power of [removes; deposes] kings and ·gives their power to new [sets up] kings. He gives wisdom to those who are wise and knowledge to those who understand.

22.verse: He ·makes known [reveals] ·secrets that are deep and hidden [deep and secret things]; he knows what is hidden in darkness, and light ·is all around [dwells with] him.

23.verse: I thank you and praise you, God of my ·ancestors [fathers], because you have given me wisdom and ·power [might]. You told me what we asked of you; you told us about the king’s ·dream [matter].”

24.verse: The Meaning of the Dream - Then Daniel went to Arioch, the man King Nebuchadnezzar had ·chosen [assigned; delegated] to ·kill [put to death; destroy] the wise men of Babylon. Daniel said to him, “Don’t ·put the wise men of Babylon to death [kill/destroy the wise men of Babylon]. Take me to the king, and I will ·tell him what his dream means [give him its interpretation].”

25.verse: Very quickly Arioch took Daniel to the king and said, “I have found a man among the ·captives [sons of the exiles] from Judah who can tell the king ·what his dream means [its interpretation].”

26.verse: The king asked Daniel, ·who was also called [whose name was] Belteshazzar [1:7], “Are you able to tell me what I dreamed and ·what it means [its interpretation]?”

27.verse: Daniel answered, “No wise man, magician [enchanter], ·fortune-teller [diviner], or exorcist can explain to the king the ·secret [mystery; v. 11] he has asked about.

28.verse: But there is a God in heaven who ·explains [reveals] ·secret things [mysteries], and he has ·shown [made known to] King Nebuchadnezzar what will happen ·at a later time [in the future; in the latter days]. This is your dream, the vision ·you saw [of your head] while lying on your bed:

29.verse: O king, as you were lying ·there [on your bed], you thought about things to come. God, who can ·tell people about [reveal] ·secret things [mysteries], ·showed [made known to] you what is going to happen.

30.verse: God also ·told [revealed] this ·secret [mystery] to me, not because I have greater wisdom than any other living person, but so that you may know ·what it means [its interpretation]. In that way you will understand ·what went through your mind [the thoughts of your heart/mind].

31.verse: “O king, in your ·dream [vision] you saw a ·huge [great], ·shiny [extraordinarily bright], and frightening statue in front of you.

32.verse: The head of the statue was made of ·pure [fine] gold. Its chest and arms were made of silver. Its ·stomach [middle; torso] and ·the upper part of its legs [its thighs] were made of bronze.

33.verse: ·The lower part of the [Its] legs were made of iron, while its feet were made partly of iron and partly of ·baked clay [pottery; terra cotta].

34.verse: While you were looking at the statue, you saw a rock cut free [from a mountain, perhaps “the mountain of the God’s temple”; Is. 2:2; Mic. 4:1], but ·no human being touched the rock [not by hands; implying God did it]. It hit the statue on its feet of iron and ·clay [pottery; terra cotta; its weak point] and ·smashed them [broke them in pieces].

35.verse: Then the iron, ·clay [pottery; terra cotta], bronze, silver, and gold broke to pieces ·at the same time [or totally]. They became like chaff on a threshing floor in the summertime; the wind blew them away, and there was nothing left. Then the rock that hit the statue became a very large mountain that filled the whole earth.

36.verse: “That was your dream. Now we will tell the king ·what it means [its interpretation].

37.verse: O king, you are the ·greatest king [king of kings]. God of heaven has given you a kingdom, ·power [sovereignty], strength, and ·glory [honor].

38.verse: Wherever people, wild animals, and birds live, God made you ruler over them. King Nebuchadnezzar, you are the head of gold.

39.verse: “Another kingdom will ·come [rise up] after you, but ·it will not be as great as [inferior to] yours [perhaps the Medes or the Medo-Persians]. Next a third kingdom, the bronze part, will rule over the earth [perhaps the Persians or the Greeks].

40.verse: Then there will be a fourth kingdom, strong as iron [perhaps the Greeks or the Romans]. In the same way that iron crushes and smashes things to pieces, the fourth kingdom will smash and crush all the other kingdoms [these kingdoms might not be specific kingdoms but symbolic of a series of unnamed oppressive nations].

41.verse: “You saw that the statue’s feet and toes were partly ·baked [pottery] clay and partly iron. That means the fourth kingdom will be a divided kingdom. It will have some of the strength of iron in it, just as you saw iron was mixed with ·clay [or pottery; or terra cotta].

42.verse: The toes of the statue were partly iron and partly ·clay [or pottery; or terra cotta]. So the fourth kingdom will be partly strong [like iron] and partly ·breakable [brittle; like baked clay].

43.verse: You saw the iron mixed with ·clay [pottery; terra cotta], but iron and ·clay [pottery; terra cotta] do not hold together. In the same way the people of the fourth kingdom will be a mixture, but they will not be united as one people.

44.verse: “During the ·time [days] of those kings, the God of heaven will set up another kingdom that will never be destroyed [the kingdom of God] or given to another group of people. This kingdom will crush all the other kingdoms and bring them to an end [v. 40], but it will ·continue [stand] forever.

45.verse: “King Nebuchadnezzar, you saw a rock cut from a mountain, but ·no human being touched it [not by hand]. The rock broke the iron, bronze, ·clay [or pottery; or terra cotta], silver, and gold to pieces. In this way the great God ·showed [made known to] you what will happen. The dream is ·true [certain], and you can trust this ·explanation [interpretation].”

46.verse: Then King Nebuchadnezzar fell ·facedown on the ground [on his face] in front of Daniel. The king ·honored [or worshiped] him and commanded that an ·offering [or grain/gift/tribute offering] and incense be ·presented [offered] to him.

47.verse: Then the king said to Daniel, “Truly I know your God is the ·greatest of all [God of] gods, the Lord of all the kings. He ·tells people about things they cannot know [reveals mysteries]. I know this is true, because you were able to ·tell [reveal] these ·secret things [mysteries] to me.”

48.verse: Then the king gave Daniel many gifts plus an important position in his kingdom. Nebuchadnezzar made him ruler over the ·whole area [province] of Babylon and put him in charge of all the wise men of Babylon.

49.verse: Daniel asked the king to ·make [appoint] Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego leaders over the ·area [province] of Babylon, so the king did as Daniel asked. Daniel ·himself became one of the people who stayed [stayed] at the royal court.

1.verse: The Gold Idol and Blazing Furnace - King Nebuchadnezzar made a gold statue ·ninety feet [sixty cubits] high and ·nine feet [six cubits] wide [unclear whether the statue was of Nebuchadnezzar or a Babylonian god like Marduk] and set it up on the plain of Dura [from a Babylonian word meaning “wall” or “fortress”] in the ·area [province] of Babylon.

2.verse: Then he ·called for the leaders: […sent for] the ·governors [satraps], ·assistant governors [prefects], ·captains of the soldiers [governors], ·people who advised the king [counselors], ·keepers of the treasury [treasurers], ·judges [justices], ·rulers [magistrates], and all other officers ·in his kingdom [of the provinces]. He wanted them to ·come [assemble] ·to the special service for [for the dedication of] the statue he had set up.

3.verse: So ·they all [the satraps, prefects, governors, counselors, treasurers, justices, magistrates, and all other officers of the provinces] came for the ·special service [dedication] and stood in front of the statue that King Nebuchadnezzar had set up.

4.verse: Then the herald [someone who made royal announcements] said in a loud voice, “People, nations, and those of every language, this is what you are commanded to do:

5.verse: When you hear the sound of the horns, flutes, lyres, zithers [a string instrument], harps, pipes, and all the other musical instruments, you must ·bow [fall] down and worship the gold statue that King Nebuchadnezzar has set up.

6.verse: Anyone who doesn’t ·bow [fall] down and worship will immediately be thrown into a blazing furnace.”

7.verse: Now people, nations, and those who spoke every language were there. When they heard the sound of the horns, flutes, lyres, zithers [v. 5], pipes, and all the other musical instruments, they ·bowed [fell] down and worshiped the gold statue King Nebuchadnezzar had set up.

8.verse: Then some ·Babylonians [Chaldeans] came up to the king and ·began speaking against [denounced; ate pieces of] the men of Judah.

9.verse: They said to King Nebuchadnezzar, “O king, live forever!

10.verse: O king, you ·gave a command [set a decree] that everyone who heard the horns, lyres, zithers [v. 5], harps, pipes, and all the other musical instruments would have to ·bow [fall] down and worship the gold statue.

11.verse: Anyone who wouldn’t ·do this [fall down and worship] was to be thrown into a blazing furnace.

12.verse: O king, there are some men of Judah whom you ·made officers in [appointed/delegated over] the ·area [province] of Babylon that did not pay attention to your order. Their names are Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego. They do not serve your gods and do not worship the gold statue you have set up.”

13.verse: Nebuchadnezzar ·became very angry [flew into a rage] and called for Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego. When they were brought to the king,

14.verse: Nebuchadnezzar said, “Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego, is it true that you do not serve my gods nor worship the gold statue I have set up?

15.verse: In a moment you will again hear the sound of the horns, flutes, lyres, zithers [v. 5], harps, pipes, and all the other musical instruments. If you ·bow [fall] down and worship the statue I made, that will be good. But if you do not worship it, you will immediately be thrown into the blazing furnace. What god will be able to ·save [rescue; deliver] you from my ·power [hands] then?”

16.verse: Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego answered the king, saying, “Nebuchadnezzar, we do not need to defend ourselves to you.

17.verse: If you throw us into the blazing furnace, the God we ·serve [fear; Prov. 1:7] is able to save us from the furnace. He will save us from your ·power [hand], O king.

18.verse: But even if God does not save us, we want you, O king, to know this: We will not serve your gods or worship the gold statue you have set up [Ex. 20:3–6].”

19.verse: Then Nebuchadnezzar was furious with Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego, and ·he changed his mind [or his appearance changed; his image/visage of his face changed]. He ordered the furnace to be heated seven times hotter than usual.

20.verse: Then he commanded some of the ·strongest soldiers in his army [men mighty in strength] to ·tie up [bind] Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego and throw them into the blazing furnace.

21.verse: So ·Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego [the men] were ·tied up [bound] and thrown into the blazing furnace while still wearing their ·robes [tunics], trousers, turbans, and other clothes.

22.verse: The king’s command was ·very strict [urgent], and the furnace was made so hot that the flames killed the strong soldiers who threw Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego into the furnace.

23.verse: Firmly tied, Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego fell into the blazing furnace.

24.verse: Then King Nebuchadnezzar was so surprised that he ·jumped to his feet [rose up in haste]. He asked the men who advised him, “Didn’t we tie up only three men and throw them into the fire?” They answered, “·Yes [True], O king.”

25.verse: The king said, “Look! I see four men walking around in the fire. They are not ·tied [bound] up, and they are not ·burned [hurt]. The fourth man looks like a son of the gods [a divine figure].”

26.verse: Then Nebuchadnezzar ·went to [approached] the opening of the blazing furnace and shouted, “Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego, come out! Servants of the Most High God, come here!” So Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego came out of the fire.

27.verse: When they came out, the ·governors [satraps], ·assistant governors [prefects], ·captains of the soldiers [governors], and ·royal advisers [counselors] crowded around them and saw that the fire had ·not harmed [no power over] their bodies. Their hair was not ·burned [singed], their ·robes [tunics] were not burned, and they didn’t even smell like smoke!

28.verse: Then Nebuchadnezzar said, “·Praise [Blessed be] the God of Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego. Their God has sent his ·angel [or messenger] and ·saved [rescued; delivered] his servants from the fire! These three men trusted their God and ·refused to obey [defied] ·my [the king’s] command. They were willing to ·die [forfeit/yield up their bodies] rather than serve or worship any god other than their own God.

29.verse: So I now give this ·command [decree]: Anyone from any nation or ·language [tongue] who says anything against the God of Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego will be torn ·apart [limb from limb] and have his house turned into a pile of stones [2:5; Ezra 6:11]. No other god can ·save [rescue; deliver] his people like this.”

30.verse: Then the king promoted Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego in the ·area [province] of Babylon.

1.verse: Nebuchadnezzar’s Dream of a Tree - King Nebuchadnezzar to the people, nations, and ·those who speak every language [tongues that live] in all the world [a typical letter opening]: ·I wish you peace and great wealth [May your peace/prosperity increase]!

2.verse: The Most High God has done ·miracles [signs] and wonderful things for me that I am happy to tell you about.

3.verse: His wonderful acts are great, and his ·miracles [signs] are mighty. His kingdom ·goes on forever [is an eternal kingdom], and his ·rule [sovereignty] continues from ·now on [generation to generation].

4.verse: I, Nebuchadnezzar, was ·happy [at ease] in my house and ·successful [living luxuriously] at my palace,

5.verse: but I ·had [saw] a dream that ·made me afraid [disturbed me]. As I was lying on my bed, I saw ·pictures [fantasies] and visions in my ·mind [head] that ·alarmed [scared; terrified] me.

6.verse: So I ·ordered [set a decree for] all the wise men of Babylon to ·come [be presented] to me and tell me ·what my dream meant [its interpretation].

7.verse: The ·fortune-tellers [diviners], ·magicians [enchanters], ·wise men [Chaldeans; 2:2], and exorcists came, and I told them about the dream. But they could not tell me ·what it meant [its interpretation].

8.verse: Finally, Daniel came to me. (I called him Belteshazzar ·to honor [after the name of] my god [1:7], because ·the spirit of the holy gods [or a holy, divine spirit] is in him.) I told my dream to him.

9.verse: I said, “Belteshazzar, you are the ·most important of all [chief of] the ·fortune-tellers [diviners]. I know that ·the spirit of the holy gods [or a holy, divine spirit] is in you, so there is no ·secret [mystery] that is too ·hard for you to understand [difficult for you]. ·This was what I dreamed [The dream I saw]; tell me ·what it means [its interpretation].

10.verse: These are the visions [of my head] I saw while I was lying in my bed: I looked, and there in front of me was a tree standing in the ·middle [center] of the earth. And it was very tall.

11.verse: The tree grew large and strong. The top ·touched [reached] the ·sky [heavens] and could be seen ·from anywhere on [to the ends of the] earth.

12.verse: The leaves of the tree were beautiful. It had plenty of good fruit on it, enough food for everyone. The ·wild animals [animals of the field] found shelter under the tree, and the birds of the ·sky [heavens] lived in its branches. Every animal ate from it.

13.verse: “As I was looking ·at those things in the vision while lying [at the visions of my head] on my bed, I saw an ·observer, a holy angel [holy watcher] coming down from heaven.

14.verse: He spoke very loudly and said, ‘Cut down the tree and cut off its branches. Strip off its leaves and scatter its fruit. Let the animals under the tree ·run away [flee], and ·let the birds in its branches fly away [the birds from its branches].

15.verse: But leave the stump and its roots in the ground with a band of iron and bronze around it; let it stay in the field with the grass around it. “‘Let the man become wet with dew of ·the sky [heaven], and let him live among the animals [of the field] and ·plants [grass] of the earth.

16.verse: Let ·him not think like a human any longer [his heart/mind be changed from human; he will be deranged], but let him have the ·mind [heart] of an animal for seven ·years [periods; times].

17.verse: “‘The ·observers [watchers; v. 13] gave this ·command [decree]; the holy ones declared the ·sentence [decision]. This is so all people may know that the Most High God ·rules [is sovereign] over every kingdom ·on earth [of humans]. God gives those kingdoms to anyone he wants, and he chooses people to rule them who are ·not proud [low].’

18.verse: “That is what I, King Nebuchadnezzar, dreamed. Now Belteshazzar [another name for Daniel; 1:7], tell me ·what the dream means [its interpretation]. None of the wise men in my kingdom can explain ·it to me [its interpretation], but you can, because ·the spirit of the holy gods [or a holy, divine spirit] is in you.”

19.verse: Daniel Explains the Dream - Then Daniel, ·who was called [whose name is] Belteshazzar [1:7], was very quiet for a while, because his understanding of the dream ·frightened [scared; terrified] him. So the king said, “Belteshazzar, do not let the dream or its ·meaning [interpretation] ·make you afraid [terrify you].” Then Belteshazzar answered, “My master, I wish the dream were about your enemies, and I wish its ·meaning [interpretation] were for those who are against you!

20.verse: You saw a tree in your dream that grew large and strong. Its top ·touched [reached] the ·sky [heavens], and it could be seen from all over the earth.

21.verse: Its leaves were beautiful, and it had plenty of fruit for everyone to eat. It was a home for the ·wild animals [animals of the field], and its branches were nesting places for the birds of the ·sky [heavens].

22.verse: O king, you are that tree! You have become great and powerful, like the tall tree that ·touched [reached] the ·sky [heavens]. Your ·power [sovereignty] reaches to the ·far parts [ends] of the earth.

23.verse: “O king, you saw an ·observer, a holy angel [holy watcher], coming down from heaven who said, ‘Cut down the tree and destroy it. But leave the stump and its roots in the ground with a band of iron and bronze around it; leave it in the field with the grass. Let him become wet with dew and live like a ·wild animal [animal of the field] for seven ·years [periods; times].’

24.verse: “This is the ·meaning of the dream [interpretation], O king. The Most High God has ·commanded [decreed] these things to happen to my master the king:

25.verse: “·That very cruel and hated ruler [He] will have a large army that he will use to stir up his strength and ·courage [heart]. 29.verse: “At the ·right [appointed] time ·the king of the North [he] will attack the king of the South again, but this time ·he will not be successful as he was before [it will not be as before].

32.verse: ·The king of the North [He] will tell lies and cause those who have ·not obeyed God [transgressed the agreement/covenant/treaty] to ·be ruined [become godless]. But those who know God and obey him will be strong and fight back.

37.verse: ·The king of the North [He] will ·not care about [pay no attention to] the gods ·his ancestors worshiped [of his ancestors/fathers; he replaced the worship of Apollos with that of Zeus] or the god ·that women worship [desired/coveted/favored by women; perhaps Adonis or Dionysius]. 44.verse: But the king of the North will hear ·news [reports] from the east and the north that will make him ·afraid [terrified] and angry. He will go to [devastate and] destroy completely many.

45.verse: He will ·set up [pitch] his royal tents between the sea and the beautiful holy mountain [Zion, the location of the Temple]. But, finally, his end will come, and no one will help him.

1.verse: The Time of the End - “At that time Michael, the great prince [angel] who ·protects [stands by] your people [10:13, 21], will ·stand up [arise]. There will be a time of ·much trouble [distress], the worst time since nations have been on earth, but at that time your people will be ·saved [rescued]. ·Everyone whose name is written in God’s book will be saved [All who are found written in the book; of life; Ex. 32:32; Ps. 69:28; Rev. 20:12].

2.verse: Many people who ·have already died [are sleeping in the land of the dust] will ·live again [wake up]. Some will wake up to life forever, but some will wake up to ·shame [reproach] and ·disgrace [abhorrence] forever [Is. 26:19].

3.verse: The ·wise [insightful; 11:33, 35] people will shine like the ·brightness of the sky [firmament; dome; expanse; Gen. 1:6]. Those who teach ·others [the many] ·to live right [righteousness] will shine like stars forever and ever.

4.verse: “But you, Daniel, ·close up the book and seal it [keep the words secret and seal the book]. ·These things will happen at the time of the end […until the time of the end]. Many people will go here and there to ·find true [increase] knowledge [Amos 8:12].”

5.verse: Then I, Daniel, looked, and saw two other men. One was standing on ·my side [one bank] of the river, and the other was standing on the ·far side [other bank].

6.verse: The man who was dressed in linen was standing ·over the water in the river [or upstream]. One of the two men spoke to him and asked, “How long will it be before these ·amazing things [wonders] come ·true [to an end]?”

7.verse: The man dressed in linen, who stood ·over the water [or upstream], raised his ·hands [right hand and his left; a solemn vow] toward heaven. And I heard him swear by the ·name of God who lives forever [life of the Eternal One], “It will be for ·three and one-half years [a time; two times, and half]. The ·power [hand] of the holy people will finally be ·broken [shattered], and then all these things will ·come true [be completed].”

8.verse: I ·heard the answer [listened], but I did not really understand, so I asked, “Master, what will ·happen after all these things come true [be the outcome of these things]?”

9.verse: He answered, “Go your way, Daniel. The ·message [word] is ·closed up [secret] and sealed until the time of the end.

10.verse: Many people will be made clean, pure, and ·spotless [refined], but the wicked will continue to be wicked. Those wicked people will not understand these things, but the ·wise [insightful] will understand them.

11.verse: “The ·daily [regular] sacrifice [8:12] will be ·stopped [turned away]. Then, after 1,290 days from that time, ·a blasphemous object that brings destruction [the abomination of desolation; 11:31] will be set up.

12.verse: Those who wait for the end of the 1,335 days will be ·happy [blessed].

13.verse: “As for you, Daniel, go your way until the end. You will get your rest, and at the end you will rise to receive your reward.”
